Highlights

  • Workday Recognized as Cloud ERP Leader (Gartner Magic Quadrant, 2025-10-15): Read more
    Workday has reasserted its position as a Leader in the 2025 Gartner® Magic Quadrant™ for Cloud ERP for Service-Centric Enterprises, marking its fourth year at the pinnacle. This honor highlights Workday’s relentless drive in fusing agentic AI and advanced ML into its platform, which underpins HR and finance transformation for a broad customer base. For Deloitte, this validation strengthens our client-side recommendations and substantiates the business case for Workday-led AI transformation, mitigating vendor concerns during multi-cloud tenders.
  • Oracle, AWS, UKG, and SAP Escalate Agentic AI Competition (Oct 14–17, 2025): Oracle details | AWS details | UKG details | SAP Joule
    This week ushered in substantial innovation: Oracle’s new Fusion agent marketplace and Autonomous AI Lakehouse bolster modular agent development, AWS debuts its agentic AI-native Quick Suite, UKG expands real-time AI HR automation via Bryte, and SAP broadens Joule agent adoptions. These advances reinforce era-defining trends: multi-agent, marketplace-driven SaaS, and deep cloud-native orchestration. For Deloitte, client conversations now require nuanced, insight-led advice on agent architecture, data strategy, and platform integration.
  • KPMG, Deloitte, EY Drive Agentic AI Drills and Governance (2025-10-14…10-17): KPMG report | Deloitte best practices
    This week saw KPMG spotlight business value through interconnected agent models, EY set the tone on responsible multi-agent design, and Deloitte formalize orchestration guidelines within regulated SaaS. Deloitte’s delivery needs to embrace these reference architectures and frameworks—especially in regulated and global settings—to sustain trust and differentiated value in Workday transformations.
  • Workday’s Higher Education Momentum and Illuminate AI Agents Expansion (2025-10-15): Workday press release
    With over 650 Higher Ed institutions adopting Workday’s AI portfolio, Illuminate AI agents are now proven in complex, process-sensitive environments. For Deloitte’s sector practices, this is a scalable reference model accelerating transformation programs, with agentic AI use cases at the core.
  • Patterns Emergent: Multi-Agent Marketplaces, Orchestration, and Responsible AI: Deloitte agentic AI governance
    The agentic shift is visible across SaaS: agent marketplaces (Workday, Oracle), orchestration-first architectures (AWS, SAP), and modular extensibility. Analyst and GSI commentary reinforce that the winning playbook for consulting now demands multi-agent orchestration skills plus embedded AI risk frameworks.

What changed this week

The SaaS ecosystem for agentic AI entered a new competitive phase as Workday earned consecutive Gartner leader status, Oracle launched a comprehensive agent marketplace with open agentic capabilities, AWS furthered native agentic suites, and UKG & SAP rapidly matured their own agent frameworks. Integration, extensibility, and trust frameworks have become table stakes, while modularity and orchestration drive procurement and architectural decisions. Analyst and GSI perspectives this week remained in strong alignment—value creation in SaaS now hinges on client orchestration of interoperable agents, underpinned by rigorous risk and governance protocols.
For Deloitte, these changes require transformation of sales narratives, enablement, and delivery models, foregrounding agent comparison, ecosystem architecture, and responsible AI consulting. The window for advisory differentiation will tighten as vendor solutions converge and commoditize—expertise in governance and multi-vendor orchestration will separate market leaders.

Competitive Watch

  • Oracle: Oracle expands agents and open marketplace. Oracle’s push targets complex enterprises with modular, extensible AI and quick onboarding for ISV partners; for Deloitte and Workday, be prepared to address ‘suite consolidation’ vs. best-of-breed debates for clients and ensure orchestration is tightly governed and value-focused.
  • AWS: Amazon Quick Suite launch demonstrates what cloud-native, agentic extensibility could mean for procurement, scalability, and innovation speed; Deloitte should leverage Workday’s own agent framework and integration cloud as counterpoints, and provide robust guidance for multi-cloud clients.
  • UKG: Bryte AI agents launch intensifies competitive claims on automation and experience—Deloitte’s Workday advisory can win by translating technical agent innovation into onboarding, reskilling, and governance outcomes with clear client value.
  • SAP: Joule digital agent ramp-up requires Deloitte’s Workday teams to offer nuanced, use-case-centric agent core comparisons to help large clients rationalize and optimize investments.

Enablement

  • Agentic AI Orchestration & Responsible AI Best Practices: Deloitte Orchestration Playbook—equips teams to address risk, compliance, and modular deployment issues for every client engagement.
  • Multi-Vendor AI Agent Ecosystems: KPMG Agentic AI Advantage—deepens ability to map and contrast features and value of top agent frameworks.
  • Workday Illuminate™ & Industry AI Agents: Illuminate Program Expansion—practitioners accelerate client rollouts and sectoral solutioning from proven templates.

Actions for Next Week

  • Leverage new Gartner Magic Quadrant recognition to drive client confidence and mitigate competitive FUD in live pursuits.
  • Mobilize sector teams on Workday Illuminate™ agent value and develop process redesign case studies for verticals such as education.
  • Bring together solution and architecture leads for cross-vendor agent framework comparison sessions and partner playbook updates.
  • Infuse best practices in responsible agent orchestration, leveraging latest GSI whitepapers and frameworks.
  • Activate ISV/joint solutioning tracks with focus on agent extensibility and orchestration integrations in large deals.

Risks & Mitigations

  • Risk: Marketplace confusion and complexity among clients due to aggressive agentic SaaS competition.
    Mitigation: Lead clear, business-value-led agent strategy workshops and actively recommend tailored architectures grounded in client needs.
  • Risk: Governance and compliance risks from fragmented or poorly orchestrated agent deployments.
    Mitigation: Integrate leading GSI frameworks and deploy continuous governance at both pilot and scaled production phases.
  • Risk: Evolving delivery skillset gaps relating to orchestration and multi-agent, multi-cloud environments.
    Mitigation: Launch structured enablement and cross-training spanning top platforms aligned to key client verticals.

All Sources

  • Workday Recognized as a Leader – Gartner Magic Quadrant 2025
  • Oracle Advances Enterprise AI with New Agents Across Fusion
  • KPMG: Agentic AI advantage
  • Workday’s Higher Education Momentum Accelerates
  • Deloitte: Agentic AI Orchestration, Governance, and Best Practices
  • AWS Launches Amazon Quick Suite
  • UKG Unveils Bryte AI Agents
  • Joule in SAP SuccessFactors
  • Workday Illuminate™ Expands with New AI Agents

- Create an **executive-grade synthesis (1200–1500 words)** with deep analysis and contextual insights.
- Each cited source should be summarized in **2–3 paragraphs**, explaining:

- Include quantified insights or examples where possible.
- Do not fabricate; rely strictly on the SOURCE LIST URLs.

- Return JSON only (no Markdown or prose outside the object).

Return JSON ONLY in this exact shape (no code fences, no extra text):

{
  "type": "daily or weekly",
  "run_date": "YYYY-MM-DD",
  "title": "Short headline",
  "priority_focus": "1–2 sentences on what matters most now",
  "highlights": [
    { "headline": "…", "why_it_matters": "…", "source_url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "competitive_watch": [
    { "competitor": "Name", "move": "…", "implication": "…" }
  ],
  "enablement": [
    { "skill": "Topic", "resource_url": "https://…", "90_day_outcome": "…" }
  ],
  "actions_next_week": ["…"],
  "risks": [
    { "risk": "…", "mitigation": "…" }
  ],
  "sources": [
    { "title": "…", "url": "https://…" }
  ],
  "html_body": "<h2>…</h2> (well-formatted HTML with <a href="https://…">links</a>; no scripts/external CSS)",
  "plain_text_body": "Text-only with visible URLs"
}

Parameters:
- Set "run_date" to TODAY_ET = 2025-10-19.
- For DAILY: set "type":"daily"; target ~1000 words; prefer items in the last 48h (from 2025-10-18 to 2025-10-19); include publication dates in highlight text.
- For WEEKLY: set "type":"weekly"; target 2000–2500 words; restrict to 2025-10-12…2025-10-19; include <h3>What changed this week</h3> and publication dates in highlight text.
- Section order for html_body: Highlights; Competitive Watch; Enablement; Actions for Next Week; Risks & Mitigations; All Sources.
- Every item must include at least one absolute URL (https://…).
- Keep total HTML under ~25KB.

ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS
- For every highlight and competitive_watch item, include a 2–3 paragraph detailed summary within the "why_it_matters" text.
- Where relevant, compare perspectives across multiple sources.
- Include a clear "so what" statement for Deloitte’s Workday practice.
- Ensure all cited URLs appear in the `sources` array and inside the `html_body` link text.
- Keep factual accuracy and avoid speculation.

Analyst and GSI commentary reinforce that the winning playbook for consulting now demands multi-agent orchestration skills plus embedded AI risk frameworks.</li>\\n</ul>\\n\\n<h3>What changed this week</h3>\\n<p>The SaaS ecosystem for agentic AI entered a new competitive phase as Workday earned consecutive Gartner leader status, Oracle launched a comprehensive agent marketplace with open agentic capabilities, AWS furthered native agentic suites, and UKG & SAP rapidly matured their own agent frameworks. Integration, extensibility, and trust frameworks have become table stakes, while modularity and orchestration drive procurement and architectural decisions. Analyst and GSI perspectives this week remained in strong alignment—value creation in SaaS now hinges on client orchestration of interoperable agents, underpinned by rigorous risk and governance protocols.<br/>For Deloitte, these changes require transformation of sales narratives, enablement, and delivery models, foregrounding agent comparison, ecosystem architecture, and responsible AI consulting. The window for advisory differentiation will tighten as vendor solutions converge and commoditize—expertise in governance and multi-vendor orchestration will separate market leaders.</p>\\n\\n<h2>Competitive Watch</h2>\\n<ul>\\n  <li><strong>Oracle:</strong> <a href=\\\"https://markets.ft.com/data/announce/detail?dockey=600-202510150810PR_NEWS_USPRX____SF98320-1\\\">Oracle expands agents and open marketplace</a>. Oracle’s push targets complex enterprises with modular, extensible AI and quick onboarding for ISV partners; for Deloitte and Workday, be prepared to address ‘suite consolidation’ vs. best-of-breed debates for clients and ensure orchestration is tightly governed and value-focused.</li>\\n  <li><strong>AWS:</strong> <a href=\\\"https://www.infoq.com/news/2025/10/aws-quick-suite\\\">Amazon Quick       "content": "| Agentic search (preview) | Parallel query execution pipeline of multiple subqueries, returning a response designed for RAG workloads and agent consumer. Queries can be vector or keyword search. Semantic ranking ensures the best results of subquery are included in the final response structure. This is the recommended approach for RAG patterns based on Azure AI Search. | [...] Azure AI Search, build an agentic retrieval pipeline in a custom solution. The agentic pipeline is designed specifically for the RAG pattern. You write code that calls Azure AI Search APIs designed for chat completion model integration with your indexed contet.\n Azure AI Foundry, use a vector index and retrieval augmentation.\n Azure OpenAI, use a search index with or without vectors.\n Azure Machine Learning, use a search index as a vector store in a prompt flow. [...] Except for features currently in preview, Azure AI Search doesn't provide native LLM integration for prompt flows or chat preservation, so you need to write code that handles orchestration and state. You can review demo source (Azure-Samples/azure-search-openai-demo), updated for agentic retrieval, for a blueprint of what a full solution entails. We also recommend Azure AI Foundry to create RAG-based Azure AI Search solutions that integrate with LLMs.\n\n## Searchable content in Azure AI Search",

[...] [AR]: Everything starts with the use case. When we think about the customer’s needs, we usually define the level of autonomy from assisting, to advising and eventually delegating the goal to an AI agent. So, everything starts there.       "url": "https://www.ey.com/en_us/consulting/agentic-ai/how-to-embed-responsible-ai-into-multi-agent-systems",
      "title": "How to embed responsible AI into multi-agent systems",
      "content": "The limited centralized oversight in multi-agent systems raises questions about the extent of human control over autonomous agents. This lack of oversight can lead to ethical dilemmas and unintended consequences, making it essential for organizations to establish governance frameworks that balance autonomy with necessary human intervention.\n ## [...] Autonomy captures the degree to which an agent can act and make decisions independently. Highly autonomous agents can sense their environment, evaluate options and act with minimal human intervention, driving efficiency and responsiveness at scale. However, this independence heightens the need for robust oversight, ethical safeguards and accountability frameworks. At the other end of the spectrum, low-autonomy agents are capable of executing basic, repetitive tasks but depend heavily on humans [...] ◦ High autonomy: Minimal human involvement, enabling scalability but requiring strong governance. ◦ Low autonomy: Limited independence, relying on frequent human direction.",

[...] The orchestration layer plays a pivotal role in Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) solutions, acting as the control system that manages how different components of the solution interact. In a typical RAG pipeline, the orchestration layer coordinates the retrieval of relevant data or documents and ensures that this data is passed to the generation model (often a large language model or LLM).       "url": "https://docs.workato.com/workato-concepts.html",
      "title": "Concepts | Workato Docs",
      "content": "### # Steps and actions\n\nA recipe executes steps each time a trigger event occurs. Every recipe requires at least one step. The simplest step is an action, such as creating an organization in Zendesk.\n\nAn example of an action\n\nSteps in Workato can include actions, conditional actions, list actions, actions that call other recipes, or try/catch blocks.\n\nLearn more about recipe steps and actions.\n\n### # Datatree and datapills\n\n Video guide: Datatree, data mapping, and data types [...] A recipe is an automated workflow that executes a series of steps to integrate and process data across multiple applications. Every recipe includes a trigger that initiates the workflow and one or more actions that execute when a trigger event occurs. Recipes use connectors to interact with different apps, ensuring seamless data flow across systems. [...] A job represents the flow of a trigger event through the recipe. Each time a trigger event occurs, the recipe executes its actions. Jobs succeed when all actions execute successfully. If an error occurs, subsequent actions do not run unless error handling is configured.\n\nLearn more about jobs.\n\n#### # Job report\n\nThe job report summarizes all trigger events processed by the recipe. Each trigger event's flow through the recipe is a job.",

      "content": "| Purchased? | Maximum retention | Customizable? |\n --- \n| None | 30 days | No |\n| Enterprise Workspace | 90 days | Yes (1 hour minimum) |\n| Data Monitoring capability | 90 days | Yes (1 hour minimum) |\n\nFor customers on our usage-based pricing model, the default data retention policy for your Workato account depends on your platform plan. Refer to your pricing plan and contract to learn more. [...] If you reduce your workspace's data retention policy, the change is not retroactive. For example, if you change the retention policy from 90 days to 60 days on December 1, 2024, data from before October 2, 2024, is no longer retained by Workato. Conversely, if you extend the retention policy, the change is retroactive. For example, if you extend the retention policy from 30 days to 90 days on December 1, 2024, data from as far back as September 2, 2024, is retained. [...] Workato's data retention policy specifies how long specific types of data are stored for your account. The data retention period is 30 or 90 days from the job's completion date, depending on your workspace type and platform plan. Workato retains this data to support error recovery, duplicate detection, custom reports, and job re-runs.",

      "content": "About WorkdayWorkday is a leading provider of enterprise cloud applications for finance and human resources, helping customers adapt and thrive in a changing world.       "url": "https://www.pwc.com/gx/en/ai-services/ai-works-for-governments.pdf",
      "title": "AI works for governments",
      "content": "Our framework provides a sequenced implementation plan that prioritizes literacy and implementer capacity first while developing innovator pipelines, and defines six actions to operationalize skills: 1. Build a talent action plan including hiring, redeployment, upskilling and accessing external experts; 5. Deploy right fit upskilling program including digital, [...] enables governments to help align employees to critical roles, target proficiencies to baseline their workforce’s current state and design tailored talent strategies aligned with their AI needs. [...] experimental and on the job learning; 6. Measure progress and refine talent and learning programs as required.",

    }
  ],

      "title": "AI Risk Management Framework | NIST",
      "url": "https://www.nist.gov/itl/ai-risk-management-framework",
      "content": "In collaboration with the private and public sectors, NIST has developed a framework to better manage risks to individuals, organizations, and society associated with artificial intelligence (AI). The NIST AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) is intended for voluntary use and to improve the ability to incorporate trustworthiness considerations into the design, development, use, and evaluation of AI products, services, and systems. [...] A companion NIST AI RMF Playbook also has been published by NIST along with an AI RMF Roadmap \"), AI RMF Crosswalk \"), and various Perspectives.\n\nOn March 30, 2023, NIST launched the Trustworthy and Responsible AI Resource Center, which will facilitate implementation of, and international alignment with, the AI RMF. Examples of how other organizations are building on and using the AI RMF can be found via the AIRC’s Use Case page. [...] On July 26, 2024, NIST released NIST-AI-600-1, Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework: Generative Artificial Intelligence Profile. The profile  can help organizations identify unique risks posed by generative AI and proposes actions for generative AI risk management that best aligns with their goals and priorities.\n\nTo view public comments received on the previous drafts of the AI RMF and Requests for Information, see the AI RMF Development page.\n\n## Translations",
      "score": 0.7368747,

    {
      "title": "Artificial Intelligence Risk Management Framework ... - NIST",
      "url": "https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/ai/NIST.AI.600-1.pdf",
      "content": "cases or sectors, this document is an AI RMF cross-sectoral proﬁle. Cross-sectoral proﬁles can be used to govern, map, measure, and manage risks associated with activities or business processes common across sectors, such as the use of large language models (LLMs), cloud-based services, or acquisition. This document deﬁnes risks that are novel to or exacerbated by the use of GAI. After introducing and describing these risks, the document provides a set of suggested actions to help organizations [...] or across extended periods. Examples include immediate (and/or prolonged) emotional harm and potential risks to physical safety due to the distribution of harmful deepfake images, or the long-term eﬀect of disinformation on societal trust in public institutions. The presence of risks and where they fall along the dimensions above will vary depending on the characteristics of the GAI model, system, or use case at hand. These characteristics include but are not limited to GAI model or system [...] Scope: Risks may exist at individual model or system levels, at the application or implementation levels (i.e., for a speciﬁc use case), or at the ecosystem level – that is, beyond a single system or organizational context. Examples of the latter include the expansion of “algorithmic monocultures,3” resulting from repeated use of the same model, or impacts on access to opportunity, labor markets, and the creative economies.4 • Source of risk: Risks may emerge from factors related to the design,",
      "score": 0.7190094,

      "content": "ecosystem progresses. The AI RMF provides guidance to developers and deployers of AI systems on how to strike a practical balance between optimizing beneficial use cases and addressing potential risks.  We look forward to our continued  work with NIST as the AI ecosystem matures, new techniques and applications are developed, and further progress is made on benchmarks and metrics for AI systems.” [...] “The NIST AI Risk Management Framework is the right document at the right time that seeks to provide American leadership in the AI governance space. While having a framework and its associated playbook is a critical first step to managing the potential risk AI can pose to people and organizations, the next step in the process is even more crucial. Now, policy makers, developers, deployers, and consumers must step up and help NIST develop use cases and populate its resource center. These [...] Process, and Monitoring (PPM) framework, which represents what we believe is the gold standard for auditing AI systems. We will use NIST’s AI RMF 1.0, and future iterations, to help update the PPM framework as we apply it to a whole range of systems used in the housing and lending sectors including credit scoring, risk-based pricing, tenant screening, automated underwriting, and advertising models.\"",

      "content": "In collaboration with the private and public sectors, NIST has created a companion AI RMF playbookfor voluntary use – which suggests ways to navigate and use the AI Risk Management Framework (AI RMF) to incorporate trustworthiness considerations in the design, development, deployment, and use of AI systems. [...] The AI RMF and the Playbook are intended for voluntary use. Organizations may utilize this information by borrowing as many – or as few – suggestions as apply to their industry use case or interests.\n\nPlaybook content will evolve to enable community review and feedback about its informativeness, accuracy and specificity. The first complete version announced on March 30, 2023, includes options for filtering or tailoring information to user preferences and requirements. [...] The Playbook is based on AI RMF 1.0 (released on January 26, 2023). It includes suggested actions, references, and related guidance to achieve the outcomes for the four functions in the AI RMF: Govern, Map, Measure, and Manage. Playbook suggestions are developed based on best practices and research insights.",

      "content": "The characteristics outlined by the NIST AI RMF align well with Deloitte’s Trustworthy AI Framework and the focus on trustworthiness can help organizations to effectively utilize a variety of automated systems while feeling confident in the security and performance of their AI models.\n\n Share\n\nSkip to description)\n\n Share\n\nSkip to description)\n\n Share\n\nSkip to description)\n\nEndnotes: [...] The NIST AI RMF outlines seven characteristics for achieving responsible use of AI systems and effectively managing AI risk: valid and reliable, accountable and transparent, safe, secure and resilient, explainable and interpretable, privacy-enhanced and fair. Each characteristic builds upon the socio-technical viewpoint NIST advocates when implementing and managing AI technologies, however the accountability and transparency attributes also pertain to the external processes and context [...] To effectively leverage the NIST AI RMF, organizations should begin by assessing their current AI capabilities and strategy, as well as how it intersects with broader ERM efforts. The framework is intended to be flexible, helping enable organizations to align practices with applicable laws, regulations and norms which may differ by industry or sector.",

      "title": "Agentic Patterns and Implementation with Agentforce",
      "content": "1. Your organization's customer initiates conversation via a channel.\n2. The message routes to Agentforce, which determines scope (topics) and applies guardrails.\n3. AI composes responses using prompt templates, while Flow or Apex may trigger backend logic.\n4. Context is retrieved from Data Cloud objects, vector store, and CRM via RAG retriever.\n5. AI returns a contextual answer.\n6. If AI cannot resolve, the conversation escalates to the Service Cloud Live Agent. [...] Your organization's business activities generate continuous streams of valuable information (calls, meetings, chats, sensor data, and more), but this data disappears in real time without capture or analysis. Organizations miss the majority of actionable intelligence needed in real time and buried in ephemeral streams, leading to gaps, lost coaching [...] Conversational agents are often the front door to an organization's AI capabilities. They are defined by their ability to engage in a stateful, multi-turn dialog, acting as the primary interface through which users perform tasks and retrieve information using natural language. The goal is to deliver simple answers through automation and minimize manual interventions for routine inquiries.       "title": "Workday Illuminate™ Expands with New AI Agents for HR ...",

      "content": "About WorkdayWorkday is the enterprise AI platform for managing people, money, and agents.       "content": "AI agents in HR\n\nIn a May 2025 Gartner webinar, 44% of HR leaders said their function plans to use semiautonomous AI agent capabilities in the next 12 months. Only 2% expect to deploy fully autonomous, unsupervised agents to replace human HR workers. Notably, two-thirds of HR leaders trust that AI agents will act in ways that benefit the employee experience. [...] AI agents are autonomous or semiautonomous software entities that use AI to perceive, decide, act and achieve goals in digital or physical environments. While the terms “AI agents” and “agentic AI” are often used interchangeably, Gartner distinguishes agentic AI as a broader approach — encompassing solutions built on software entities that fully or partially qualify as AI agents.\n\nAgentic AI has generated significant buzz for its potential to boost efficiency across business processes. [...] Emerging use cases for AI agents span multiple domains. However, the space is still maturing: AI agents range from simple, supervised tools to systems capable of independent decision making. Many vendors are rebranding basic chatbots and virtual assistants as “agents” without adding advanced, autonomous features.\n\nCHROs should cut through the hype and focus on high-value, practical applications. Gartner recommends starting with supervised agents that augment — not replace — human roles.",

      "url": "https://www.workday.com/en-us/perspectives/artificial-intelligence/2025/10/ai-redraws-org-chart.html",
      "title": "How AI Will Redraw the Org Chart",
      "content": "It can analyze data in seconds. But it can’t decide what matters, set priorities, or inspire people to follow. That’s still human territory.\n\nAnd our workforce knows it. In our research, employees said they’re comfortable working with AI agents as copilots. But they draw the line at being managed by them.\n\nIn other words, AI can be an advisor and even a coach. But only humans can build connections and culture. [...] This is all part of the AI paradox leaders face today: AI won’t replace managers, but it will replace the way we manage. The org chart of the future won’t be a pyramid of boxes. It will be replaced by something new that delivers maximum value for the people who matter most.\n\nImagine customers at the center of everything. Employees collaborating across silos. AI agents as copilots. And leaders orchestrating connection, not just efficiency.       "url": "https://www.servicenow.com/docs/bundle/zurich-conversational-interfaces/page/administer/virtual-agent/concept/na-va-llm-teams.html",
      "title": "Using Now Assist in Virtual Agent conversations ...",
      "content": "To use Copilot, enable streaming on your assistant and the Microsoft Teams application. Streaming for Microsoft Copilot is active by default, while streaming for Microsoft Teams is inactive by default. Confirm you have activated both to access CEA. If streaming is not activated, CEA may timeout on you without notice.\n\nIn the Zurich release, streaming is active by default and CEA is inactive by default. Contact your ServiceNow® support team to have CEA activated for your instance. [...] Note: Custom Engine Agent (CEA) is replacing Declarative Agent (DA), the prior Microsoft Copilot integration. The CEA enables Virtual Agent to be discoverable by Microsoft Copilot, with full functional access to Now Assist in Virtual Agent and multi-turn conversations.
